qas.question: Is there a single standard for HDTV color support?
Before being converted to RGB, colors are ususally broadcasted using what color space?
Colors are typically broadcast using YUV and then converted to what?
When transmitted over the internet, colors are typically to what?
What assumption is made with colors being transmitted over the internet?

answers.text: it will only be viewed only on a (sRGB) computer screen

qas.question: Is there a single standard for SDTV color support?
Before being converted to RGB, colors are not usually broadcasted using what color space?
Colors are typically broadcast using UUV and then converted to what?
When transmitted over the internet,  black and white are typically to what?

plausible_answers.text: it will only be viewed only on a (sRGB) computer screen

qas.question: What assumption is made with colors being transmitted not over the internet?

context: There is <a0_0><b5_0>no<b5_0/><a0_0/> single standard for HDTV color support. Colors are typically broadcast using a (10-bits per channel) <a1_0><b6_0>YUV<b6_0/><a1_0/> color space but, depending on the underlying image generating technologies of the receiver, are then subsequently converted to <a2_0>a <b7_0>RGB color space<b7_0/><a2_0/> using standardized algorithms. When transmitted directly through the Internet, the colors are typically pre-converted to <a3_0><b8_0>8-bit RGB channels<b8_0/><a3_0/> for additional storage savings with the assumption that <a4_0><b9_0>it will only be viewed only on a (sRGB) computer screen<b9_0/><a4_0/>. As an added benefit to the original broadcasters, the losses of the pre-conversion essentially make these files unsuitable for professional TV re-broadcasting.
